issues.title: Naming proposal `__Session`
issues.author: Jxck
issues.body:
I strongly agree with this proposal. Since I'm wondering why `__Host-` prefix lacks of `HttpOnly`.
In general, Session Cookie should have

1. Secure
1. Path=/
1. no Domain
1. HttpOnly

But last option doesn't covered by `__Host` so I need to add `HttpOnly` too.

```
Set-Cookie: __Host-session_id=xxxxxxxxxxxxxx; HttpOnly; Max-Age=${maxage}
```

So your suggestion for `__HttpOnlyHost` is `__Session` for me.

```
Set-Cookie: __Session-id=xxxxxxxxxxxxxxx; Max-Age=${maxage}
```

And it explicitly shows it's Cookie for Session Management.
So I'd love to propose alternative naming for your proposal.
Thanks.

pulls.title: tweaks to language
pulls.author: roryhewitt
pulls.body: Changed the language to indicate that the Server can only _infer_ information about a cookie received in a **Cookie** request header based on the name, since the actual implementation of the requirements occurs on the client.

comments.body:
I think we want to have both:
* Requirements on when servers should send a Set-Cookie with an __HttpOnly prefix
* What can they make of Cookie request headers that have that prefix.

I just included the first and your wording only includes the latter :)

I'll land this and then tweak. Thanks!!

pulls.title: Tweaks to 'Server Requirements' section
pulls.author: roryhewitt
pulls.body:
Updated to clarify that there are two parts to cookie 'processing' on the server:

1. The creation of the cookie via a `Set-Cookie` response header
2. The processing of an incoming cookie received in a `Cookie` request header

I have split them and used normative `MUST` in the former (because it's creating the cookie) and non-normative `indicates that` in the latter (because it's processing a cookie which could have been maliciously created by the client).
